user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1ProcessMessageBlock:
```c
static void
SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (struct SHA1Context *context)
{
  const uint32_t K[] = { 0x5A827999, 0x6ED9EBA1, 0x8F1BBCDC, 0xCA62C1D6 };
  int i;
  uint32_t temp;
  uint32_t W[80];
  uint32_t A, B, C, D, E;

  for (i = 0; i < 16; i++)
  {
    W[i] = ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4]) << 24;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 1]) << 16;
    W[i] |= ((uint32_t) context->message_block[i * 4 + 2]) << 8;
    W[i] |= context->message_block[i * 4 + 3];
  }
  for (i = 16; i < 80; i++)
  {
    W[i]
      = SHA1CircularShift (1, W[i - 3] ^ W[i - 8] ^ W[i - 14] ^ W[i - 16]);
  }
  A = context->intermediate_hash[0];
  B = context->intermediate_hash[1];
  C = context->intermediate_hash[2];
  D = context->intermediate_hash[3];
  E = context->intermediate_hash[4];
  for (i = 0; i < 20; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | ((~B) & D)) + E + W[i]
           + K[0];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 20; i < 40; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[1];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 40; i < 60; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + ((B & C) | (B & D) | (C & D)) + E
           + W[i] + K[2];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  for (i = 60; i < 80; i++)
  {
    temp = SHA1CircularShift (5, A) + (B ^ C ^ D) + E + W[i] + K[3];
    E = D;
    D = C;
    C = SHA1CircularShift (30, B);
    B = A;
    A = temp;
  }
  context->intermediate_hash[0] += A;
  context->intermediate_hash[1] += B;
  context->intermediate_hash[2] += C;
  context->intermediate_hash[3] += D;
  context->intermediate_hash[4] += E;
  context->message_block_index = 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 8.13 concerns pointer types that could be const-qualified. The only pointer visible in this function is the parameter 'struct SHA1Context *context' and all uses of that pointer are the fragments listed above (reads from message_block and intermediate_hash, and writes back to intermediate_hash and message_block_index). These are the only places where a pointer to data is accessed; local arrays and scalars (K, W, A..E, temp, i) are not pointer declarations and either are already const (K) or are local modifiable objects, so they are not relevant to Rule 8.13. No other pointer variables or pointer-typed expressions appear in this function that would need const qualification, so they are not reported for investigation.
